questions.question: Are the windows aligned vertically in the same columns across all floors?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the windows on each floor are positioned directly above each other, creating vertical columns. This vertical alignment is a common architectural feature in many residential buildings, suggesting an organized and symmetrical window design for consistent aesthetic appeal and structural support.

questions.question: Is there a red door located on the left side of the ground floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, a red door is visible on the left side of the ground floor. It is distinguishable by its distinctive color, which is a striking choice often used to create contrast and visual interest, thus making it a prominent feature.

questions.question: Is there a dark-colored door located on the right side of the ground floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, there is no door visible on the right side of the ground floor that matches a dark color description. The focus is on the distinctive details of the building. Hence, this option seems to be inapplicable or absent in this scenario.

questions.question: Does the climbing plant cover the central vertical strip of the building, spanning from near the ground floor up to the third floor?
questions.explanation: In Image B, a climbing plant is evident, winding its way from near the ground floor up along the building, covering significant parts of the facade. This distribution gives it a natural and decorative look, which is often employed in urban areas to add greenery.

questions.question: Is there a red rectangular outline enclosing a section of the building that includes three stacked windows and a balcony?
questions.explanation: In Image B, there is no red rectangular outline visible. The building is portrayed with a clear depiction of the structural elements but without any additional markings such as red outlines for highlighting.

questions.question: Are the balconies located directly outside specific windows on the second, third, and fourth floors?
questions.explanation: In Image B, the balconies are positioned directly outside the windows on the second, third, and fourth floors, showcasing a precise alignment typical in architectural designs for visual consistency and practical access to views and ventilation.
